Hubei Key Laboratory for Efficient Utilization and Agglomeration of Metallurgic Mineral Resources Wuhan University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430081 PR China Graphical abstract A series of Ce-promoted nickel supported activated carbon (NiCe x C) catalysts with different molar contents of Ce (0, 0.5 %, 1 %, 3 % and 5 %) were synthesized via a wetness co-impregnation method. Catalytic activity of CO2 dry reforming of methane (DRM) was evaluated in a non-thermal plasma (NTP)-catalytic reactor. Experimental results showed that the introduction of CeO2 could promote the NTP-catalytic DRM reaction. Specifically, NiCe1C catalyst was regarded as the best one due to its excellent conversion of CO2 (53.7 %) and CH4 (55.6 %), as well as a prominent selectivity of H2 (50.0 %) and CO (53.2 %). Moreover, it was also found that NiCe1C could achieve the highest energy efficiency (0.59 mmol kJ−1) compared with NiCe0C (0.52 mmol kJ−1). A strong dual-metals interaction between Ni and CeO2 was found to inhibit the growth of Ni particle, and improve the dispersion of Ni nanoparticles (NPs), thereby the activation energy of CH4 was reduced due to the size effect. The addition of CeO2 created more basic sites with stronger basicity of the catalyst, which was beneficial to increase the adsorption capacity of the reactants, especially the acidic gas CO2. Thus, the conversion of CO2 and CH4 were further improved. Besides, the formation of coke deposition and the participation of carbon support in the reaction could be avoided by controlling CH4/CO2 ratio in the feed gases. Keywords CO2 utilization DRM Plasma CeO2 Ni/C 1 Introduction Nowadays, almost a billion tons of CO2 are released into the atmosphere per month [1,2]. Progressively growth of CO2 level in the ambient air has led to a dangerous temperature increase at the earth’s surface [3,4]. In this case, it may be helpful to convert the greenhouse gas into the valuable chemicals [5,6]. Dry reforming of methane (DRM) utilizing CO2 C H 4 +C O 2 → 2CO+2 H 2 , Δ H 298k = 247 kJ mo l -1 to obtain syngas (H2 and CO mixtures) has gained enormous research interest on account of the simultaneous consumption of two major greenhouse gases (CO2 and CH4). Moreover, the syngas produced by DRM is an important chemical feedstock [7,8]. DRM under non-thermal plasma (NTP) assisted with Ni supported activated carbon (Ni/C) catalyst was studied in our recent work [9]. The NTP combined with Ni/C catalyst can achieve a considerable CO2 (64.6 %) and CH4 (65.7 %) conversion, as well as a yield of H2 (27.9 %) and CO (32.5 %) at 45 W. However, the energy efficiency of Ni/C catalyst (0.52 mmol kJ−1) was unsatisfactory due to the high energy consumption, which should be further improved. Additionally, the catalytic activity of NTP-catalytic DRM has a great improvement room through the developing a novel catalysts [10–12]. Recently, lanthanide or alkali elements (Ce, La, Zr, K, Ca or Mg) have been widely used as a promoter to improve catalytic performance in the catalytic DRM process [13–20]. Ce modifier, for instance, has been reported to observably increase CO2 adsorption capacity at the surfaces of catalyst, which lead to an improvement of the reaction performance in the catalytic DRM process [21,22]. Kalai et al. [23] studied the effect of Ce promotion on the activity and stability of Ni-Mg-Al HT-derived catalysts, and found that a higher Ce/Ni ratio exhibited a better activity and stability in model biogas reforming process. Goula et al. [24] reported that the enhanced activity of Ce-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was related to the larger amount of reducible active sites at the surface of the catalyst, which could enhance the oxygen storage and transport capacity. Debek et al. [25] also proved that the addition of Ce resulted in the improved activity and stability of the Ni-Mg-Al HT-derived catalysts, the key roles of Ce were assigned to increase the reducibility of Ni nanoparticles (NPs), as well as increase the basic sites. Moreover, Debek and co-workers [26] thought that the Ce promoted catalyst could hinder the transformation of amorphous carbon to graphitic carbon, thereby increasing the stability in the thermal DRM reaction. However, the knowledge of adding appropriate promoter for highly efficient NTP-catalytic DRM process is still very limited. Especially, the influence of Ce load on the Ni/C catalyst in the NTP-catalytic DRM process is still unclear. Herein, a series of NiCexC catalysts with Ce content ranging from 0 to 5 % (molar content) were prepared by the wetness co-impregnation method. The effect of Ce promoter on Ni/C catalyst properties and catalytic performance in the NTP-catalytic DRM was also studied. The conversion of reactants, yield and selectivity of syngas, H2/CO molar ratio and the reaction energy efficiency were evaluated in the NTP-catalytic reactor. Characterizations were employed to further elucidate the reaction mechanisms. 2 Experimental A series of Ce-promoted Ni/C catalysts with different molar contents of Ce (0, 0.5 %, 1 %, 3 % and 5 %) was prepared by using the wetness co-impregnation method. The content of Ni was fixed at 8 % (mole content). A commercial activated carbon was sieved to a mean particle diameter of 1.5 mm, then treated by using KOH solution, finally used as received. The predetermined amount of activated carbon was added to the mixed aqueous solution of nickel nitrate and cerium nitrate and stirred (400 rpm) at an ambient temperature for 10 h. After the drying at 378 K overnight, the solid sample was obtained. Prior to the DRM reaction, the sample was reduced via carbothermal reduction method at 923 K in N2 (50 ml·min−1) for 1 h, and then cooled down to room temperature under N2 atmosphere. Ultimately, the samples were named as NiCe0C, NiCe0.5C, NiCe1C, NiCe3C and NiCe5C, respectively. The prepared catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive spectrometry (SEM-EDS), Infrared spectra (in situ DRIFT spectrometer), CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD), as well as Thermal Gravimetric-Derivative Thermal Gravimetric (TG-DTG). The detailed synthesis, characterization and plasma-catalytic evaluation procedure of NiCe x C samples were described in the supporting information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characteristics of NiCexC catalyst The surface area and pore distribution of the catalysts were first examined by N2 physisorption (Fig. 1 ). In Fig. 1 (a), type-I isotherm with a steep slope was observed at P/P 0 < 0.1, reflecting the presence of numerous micropores. Furthermore, all the catalysts also showed a typical type-IV isotherm with H4-type steep hysteresis loop at P/P 0 = 0.43∼1.0. This phenomenon suggested that the as-prepared catalysts possessed a large number of mesopores, which featured with the typical slit-like structure [27]. Totally, NiCe x C samples had a hierarchical structure mainly associated with micro- and mesopores [28]. Table 1 listed the detailed textural properties of all the catalysts. NiCe0C catalyst had the largest specific surface area (SBET) (517.4 m2 g−1) and total pore volume (0.35 cm3 g−1). The SBET and total pore volume of NiCe x C catalysts was decreased with increasing Ce loading, and NiCe5C catalyst presented the lowest SBET (249.8 m2 g−1) and total pore volume (0.20 cm3 g−1). The distribution of pore size was shown in Fig. 1 (b). It was found that the pore size distribution of the mesopores was mainly in the range of 3.6∼4.4 nm. The addition of Ce obviously changed the regular pore structure of Ni/C catalyst. The average pore size (Dpore) was increased from 3.1 nm to 3.8 nm as the Ce content increased from 0 to 5 %. The variations probably were attributed to the fact that the pores in the catalysts were partially blocked by the incorporated Ce species [25,29]. Besides, the introduction of the metallic Ce could result in the collapse of the support pore structure [30]. The XRD patterns of NiCe x C catalysts was depicted in Fig. 2 . All catalysts presented the peaks at 44.5°, 51.9° and 76.6°, assigned to Ni (JCPDS 04-0850). Furthermore, a graphite carbon peak (26.7°) of all catalysts was clearly observed. For the catalysts with Ce loading, the characteristic peaks appeared at 28.5, 33.0, 47.5 and 56.4° corresponded to CeO2 with a face-centered cubic fluorite structure (JCPDS 34-0394). The peak intensity of Ni was clearly decreased with increasing Ce loading, which indicated that the metallic Ni in the Ce-promoted catalyst had a smaller particle size. Meanwhile, the Ni particle size estimated by Scherrer equation [31] was summarized in Table 1. The largest Ni particle size (31.1 nm) was obtained for the NiCe0C catalyst, and the Ni particle size was decreased to 23.7∼28.8 nm when introducing CeO2 into the catalysts. In other words, the addition of CeO2 into Ni/C catalyst could inhibit the growth of Ni particle size due to the enhanced strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [32,33], which could also assist nickel species to disperse more evenly on the surface of catalyst. Thus, the catalytic activity for the DRM reaction was improved [34–36]. In addition, the CeO2 particle size (calculated by Scherrer equation) increased (from 9.5 nm to 22.1 nm) with the increased Ce loading (from 0.5 % to 5 %) (Table 1). DRIFTS measurements were performed on the prepared catalysts to compare their affinities to the reactant (CO2/CH4). As shown in Fig. 3 (a), after exposing to CO2 at 303 K for 50 min, the typical peaks at 2350 cm−1 and 2335 cm−1 were observed, which were assigned to the stretching vibrations and anti-symmetric elongations of CO [37,38]. The intensity of the main peak of CO2 was obviously enhanced with the amount of Ce addition until 1 %, as shown in Fig. 3 (a), then slightly weakened with further adding Ce. This phenomenon could be ascribed to the reducing active site of adsorbing CO2 on catalyst caused by decreasing SBET and increasing CeO2 particle size (Table 1), in keeping with BET and XRD results [39,40]. Fig. 3 (b) presented the DRIFTS spectra of CH4 adsorbed on catalysts. Peaks at 1304 and 3016 cm−1 were observed, both of the peaks were ascribed to C–H bonds in methane [41]. With increasing of Ce content, the trend of the peak intensities followed the order: NiCe1C > NiCe3C > NiCe5C > NiCe0.5C > NiCe0C. The phenomena reflected that the NiCexC catalysts, particularly NiCe1C catalyst, exhibited an excellent CO2 and CH4 adsorption capability. In other words, the introduction of Ce could increase the retention time of CO2 and CH4 at the catalyst surface, thereby benefit to improve the reactants conversions [9]. CO2-TPD measurements were conducted to examine the surface basicity of the NiCe0C and NiCe1C catalysts (Fig. 4 ), which was considered to play a crucial role in the catalytic DRM reaction [42,43]. On both catalysts, two CO2 desorption peaks at 370 K and 681 K were observed, corresponding to the weak adsorption of CO2 on OH groups and moderate adsorption of CO2 on the carbon carrier, respectively [19]. Notably, two new peaks were obtained at 548 K (moderate CO2 adsorption) and 782 K (strong CO2 adsorption) for the NiCe1C catalyst, which could be associated to CO2 adsorption on the metal-oxygen pairs and O2− anions, respectively [44]. It was clear that CO2 was preferentially absorbed on the strong basic sites as Ce species were added to the catalyst, rather than C support. This result indicated that the adsorption of CO2 had changed from physical adsorption to chemical adsorption due to the addition of CeO2. In addition, the CO2 desorption quantity on NiCe1C catalyst was larger than that of NiCe0C catalyst (Table S1). In summary, the higher desorption temperature of CO2 showed the stronger basicity, and the larger desorption quantities of CO2 indicated that more basic sites were available on the NiCe1C catalyst surface [19,45]. 3.2 The evaluation of NTP-catalytic DRM Fig. 5 (a) displayed the influence of the catalysts loaded with diverse Ce molar contents (0, 0.5 %, 1 %, 3 % and 5 %) on CH4 and CO2 conversions at 40 W. Compared with NiCe0C catalyst, the combination of NTP and Ce promoted catalysts obviously raised the conversion of CO2 and CH4. When the addition of Ce content was increased from 0 to 5 %, the conversion of CH4 was enhanced monotonously (from 50.5%–58.3 %). This result could be attributed to the reason that the addition of Ce modifier promoted the formation of smaller Ni particle size (XRD), facilitating the activation of CH4 [18,46]. However, CO2 conversion presented a tendency of firstly increasing (the Ce addition varied from 0∼1 %) and then decreasing (the Ce addition was up to 5 %), consisting with the catalyst’s affinity for CO2 (Fig. 3 (a)). The highest conversion of CO2 (53.7 %) was obtained over NiCe1C catalyst. This phenomenon indicated that a certain amount of Ce addition could promote the absorption of CO2 and the activation of CO2 [19]. However, the excessive Ce addition could cause the enlargement of CeO2 particles (XRD), which would block the pores of the catalysts (SBET) and lead to the decline of CO2 adsorption (DRIFT). Thus, CO2 conversion was decreased. Kathiraser et al. [47] also reported that there was also an optimal value of 0.5 % for the addition of Ce promoter to Ni/SiO2 catalyst, and the CO2 conversion decreased from 77 % to 64 % at 1023 K as Ce content was increased to 5 %. In the current work, in view of the overall conversion of CH4 and CO2 and the reaction balance, the optimum catalyst was regarded as NiCe1C due to its considerable conversion of CO2 (53.7 %) and CH4 (55.6 %). Fig. 5 (b) showed the selectivity of H2 and CO in the NTP-catalytic DRM process. H2 selectivity gradually increased (from 44.5%–50.2 %) with increasing Ce loading (from 0 to 5 %), while CO selectivity clearly was increased until Ce content was 1 %, then decreased as the Ce content further increase. The combination of NTP with NiCe1C catalyst exhibited the highest CO selectivity (53.2 %). Compared to NTP-DRM with NiCe0C catalyst, the loading Ce in catalysts also improved the yield of H2 and CO, as shown in Fig. 5 (c). The highest CO yield (29.0 %) was obtained over NiCe1C catalyst as CO generation depended primarily on the CO2 conversion [25]. Fig. 5 (d) presented the coupling of plasma with Ce promoted catalysts increased H2/CO molar ratio, which was consistent with the effect of the catalyst on the conversion of CH4 and CO2. Moreover, H2/CO molar ratio increased with increasing Ce doping, which could be attributed to the enhancement of CH4 conversion. In this work, the optimal H2/CO ratio about 0.98 (≈ desired value of 1) was obtained over NiCe1C catalyst. Other saturated hydrocarbons (mainly C2H6, C3H8) and unsaturated hydrocarbon (mainly C2H4, C3H6 and C2H2) were detected in the NTP-catalytic DRM and the corresponding results were given in Fig. 6 . Compared to the alkanes, the amounts of unsaturated hydrocarbons were very low in the NTP-catalytic DRM reaction. The highest selectivity was C2H6 (11.7–17.8 %), followed by C3H8 (4.5–5.7 %), and the lowest was C3H6 (＜0.5 %) (Fig. 6 (a)), which was consistent with the yield (Fig. 6 (b)). All catalysts exhibited a similar selectivity and yield of C2H2. During the NTP-catalytic DRM reaction, NiCe5C catalyst exhibited the highest yield of C2H6 (9.7 %), C3H8 (2.9 %), C2H4 (0.7 %) and C3H6 (0.2 %). These results could be attributed to the significant increase of CH4 conversion resulted from the nano-size effect by smaller Ni particle sizes in the process of NTP-catalytic DRM [48]. Fig. 7 demonstrated the total energy efficiency in the NTP-catalytic DRM process. energy efficiency was defined according to Eq.1 (1) E mmol k J − 1 = CO 2 in − CO 2 out + CH 4 in − CH 4 out mol s − 1 Discharge p o w e r W Here, CO2 (in) and CH4 (in) are the total quantity of CO2 and CH4 in the feed gas, respectively. CO2 (out) and CH4 (out) are the total quantity of CO2 and CH4 in the tail gas, respectively. Obviously, compared with the NTP-catalytic DRM over NiCe0C catalyst, the coupling of the plasma and Ce-promoted catalysts had higher energy efficiency. The maximum energy efficiency (0.59 mmol kJ−1) was gained while loading NiCe1C catalyst in the NTP-catalytic DRM reactor. Table 2 compared the energy efficiency of NTP-catalytic DRM reaction under different catalysts, the total energy efficiency presented in this work was comparatively greater than that of previous reports [49–52]. During the DRM reaction, the participation in the reaction of carbon carriers is a universal concern. Therefore, the distributions of main products were investigated by changing CH4/CO2 molar ratios in the feed gases. The reaction condition was a fixed total feed rate of 50 ml min−1 and discharge power of 40 W under NiCe1C catalyst, and the results were shown in Fig. 8 and Table S2. CH4 and CO2 conversions were 45.3 % and 43.7 % as CH4/CO2 molar ratio was 3:1, and corresponding to the highest H2/CO molar ratio (2.48). This result suggested that more H2 was produced mainly by methane decomposition C H 4 → C+2 H 2 Δ H 298k = 75 kJ mo l -1 [15]. At the same time, more coke deposition could be formed, resulting in the deactivation of the catalyst. When CH4/CO2 molar ratio decreased to 1:3, namely CO2 in the feed gases was excessive, the CH4 and CO2 conversions was increased to 86.2 % and 65.6 %, respectively. The amounts of H2 and CO in the gaseous products were significantly increased, especially the CO yield was increased 4.6 times (from 9.2%–42.5 %). However, H2/CO molar ratio was dropped to 0.51. This phenomenon could be ascribed to the reaction of CO2 and the carrier carbon C O 2 +C ( support ) → 2CO Δ H 298k = -171 kJ mo l -1 [14]. Notably, when CH4/CO2 molar ratio was 1:1, the CH4 and CO2 conversions were 55.6 % and 53.7 %, respectively. Meanwhile, H2/CO molar ratio was almost 1, implying that the coke deposition was limited and the consumption of support C could be avoided. Similar results were reported by Han et al. [18], it was indicated that a high CH4/CO2 ratio favored coke generation by CH4 decomposition, while a low CH4/CO2 ratio could lead to a side reaction of CO2 e .g . C O 2 + H 2 → CO+ H 2 O . Hence, it could not only reduce the formation of coke deposition but also avoid the reaction of the carrier carbon by selecting appropriate CH4/CO2 molar ratio in the feed gases over NiCe x C catalysts. 3.3 Effect of Ce promoter on coke deposition TG-DTG technique was employed to understand the coke deposition on the catalysts surface during the NTP-catalytic DRM reaction (Fig. 9 ). TG-DTG analysis of the fresh catalysts was presented in Fig. S1. A distinct weight loss occurred at 623−873 K, which was contributed to the carbon support oxidation [9,18]. From Fig. 9, the peak at 530−600 K in the spent catalysts was the feature of the coke, attributed to the deposition of coke in the NTP-catalytic DRM reaction [53]. When the amount of Ce changed from 0 to 1 %, the coke deposition rate was basically maintained at 2.3 %·h−1 (Table 3 ). Noteworthy, the coke deposition rate dramatically increased (from 2.3–4.2 %·h−1) as the Ce addition was 5 %. The above result was consistent with the catalytic activity of NiCe x C catalysts. The addition of Ce promoter significantly decreased the particle size of Ni NPs (from XRD), which increased the conversion of CH4 monotonously (Fig. 5a). It is well known that the plasma gas phase reactions and plasma driven surface reactions could contribute to the solid carbon deposition in the NTP-catalytic DRM reaction [48]. In the gas phase reactions, CH x (x = 1–3) were generated from the electron-impact dissociation of CH4 (Eq.2–4), and the subsequent recombination of CH x radical would form higher hydrocarbons. (2) C H 4 + e − → C H 3 +H+ e − (3) C H 4 + e − → C H 2 + H 2 + e − (4) C H 4 + e − → CH+ H 2 +H+ e − In the existence of high energy electrons (＞14 eV), solid carbon could be generated and deposited on the catalyst surface under the following reactions (Eq.5–8). (5) C H 4 + e − → C+2 H 2 + e − (6) C H 3 + e − → C+ H 2 +H+ e − (7) C H 2 + e − → C+ H 2 + e − (8) CH+ e − → C+H+ e − At the surface of the catalyst, the adsorption and dissociation of CH4 are the key reaction pathways for the carbon formation C H 4 → C * + H 2 g . When the Ce load content was increased from 0.5 to 5 %, the variation of CO2 conversion followed a volcanic type (Fig. 5a), which was consisted with the result of CO2 adsorption (DRIFT). Therefore, a significantly difference between CH4 dissociation and CO2 conversion rates emerged in NiCe3C and NiCe5C catalysts. In other words, only when an optimal content of Ce was introduced, an “oxidation-reduction” balance could be established, thereby a stable activity of DRM was kept [54]. Herein, the lower amount of coke formation and the higher carbon balance (88 %) was achieved over NiCe1C catalyst. The textural properties of the spent NiCe1C catalyst were characterized by XRD, N2 physisorption in Fig. 10 . Fig. 10 (a) demonstrated that the mesoporous structure of NiCe1C catalyst was basically unchanged after 3 h NTP-catalytic DRM reaction. The micropore surface area of NiCe1C catalyst was distinctly reduced by 65.5 %, however, external surface area was only slightly decreased (8.4 %) (as listed in Table 1). Therefore, the catalyst after DRM reaction caused the reduction of BET surface area and the total pore volume, which was likely related to the loss of numerous micropores. In addition, the crystallization in spent NiCe1C catalyst was unvaried as shown in XRD pattern (Fig. 10 (b)). Fig. 10 (c), (d) presented SEM-EDS images of the fresh and spent NiCe1C catalyst. It could be found that Ni particle size (27.9 nm) of the spent NiCe1C catalyst was not obviously changed. This result was consistent with XRD analysis of the catalyst (see Table 1). Moreover, EDS mapping depicted that Ni and Ce species after the NTP-catalytic DRM reaction were still well-distributed on the AC support. 4 Conclusions In this work, a series of NiCe x C catalysts were prepared via a wetness co-impregnation method. Characterization results showed that there was a strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) between Ni and CeO2. The prepared NiCe x C catalysts posed larger pore diameter and smaller Ni particle size. Close correlations of the increased basic sites and enhanced basicity with NTP-catalytic DRM activity of NiCe x C catalyst were observed. The activity of NiCe x C catalyst was remarkably enhanced compared with un-promoted Ni/C catalyst. Among catalysts, NiCe1C was the optimal catalyst at a total flow rate of 50 ml min−1 with 1.0 CH4/CO2 molar ratio. CO2 and CH4 conversions were 53.7 % and 55.6 %, and H2 and CO selectivity were 50.0 % and 53.2 %. Moreover, the molar radio of H2/CO was 0.98. Overall, NiCe1C catalysts can be used as a promising candidate for the NTP-catalytic DRM process. CRediT authorship contribution statement Huaqin Wang: Investigation, Methodology. coredata.dc:description: A series of Ce-promoted nickel supported activated carbon (NiCe x C) catalysts with different molar contents of Ce (0, 0.5 %, 1 %, 3 % and 5 %) were synthesized via a wetness co-impregnation method. Catalytic activity of CO2 dry reforming of methane (DRM) was evaluated in a non-thermal plasma (NTP)-catalytic reactor. Experimental results showed that the introduction of CeO2 could promote the NTP-catalytic DRM reaction. Specifically, NiCe1C catalyst was regarded as the best one due to its excellent conversion of CO2 (53.7 %) and CH4 (55.6 %), as well as a prominent selectivity of H2 (50.0 %) and CO (53.2 %). Moreover, it was also found that NiCe1C could achieve the highest energy efficiency (0.59 mmol kJ−1) compared with NiCe0C (0.52 mmol kJ−1). A strong dual-metals interaction between Ni and CeO2 was found to inhibit the growth of Ni particle, and improve the dispersion of Ni nanoparticles (NPs), thereby the activation energy of CH4 was reduced due to the size effect. The addition of CeO2 created more basic sites with stronger basicity of the catalyst, which was beneficial to increase the adsorption capacity of the reactants, especially the acidic gas CO2. Thus, the conversion of CO2 and CH4 were further improved. Besides, the formation of coke deposition and the participation of carbon support in the reaction could be avoided by controlling CH4/CO2 ratio in the feed gases.
coredata.dc:title: Non-thermal plasma-enhanced dry reforming of methane and CO2 over Ce-promoted Ni/C catalysts
